job_title: Full Time Faculty in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
The Good:

I was an instructor for several years. Teaching is fun and the students are great. Faculty meetings often include food and overall this job is incredibly low stress.
cons:
The Bad:

In the multiple years I was employed here, I NEVER received the annual cost of living raise that many of my colleagues were getting. They refused to even perform my annual review which would allow me to get those raises. (That raise is about 2% a year btw) I’m sure I’m not the only one affected by this. 



The Ugly: 

Post covid, they refuse to adapt to hybrid working models/ working from home. It makes sense to be on campus when you teach. It does not make sense to have to sit in the building for another 4 hours after teaching doing administrative tasks that are done on one’s laptop. Moreover, it definitely feels like a waste of time to have to sit and twiddle your thumbs for eight hours on the days you don’t teach.

 Requiring faculty to be on ground 40 hours is a power play by the management and robs faculty of their professionalism as well as their ability to have a more meaningful work-life balance. 

I’ve seen may people get bullied by management. If you take a job here, stay off their radar. The morale on campus is in the toilet. Deans and CP do not respect faculty at all. They will pretend they to but it’s fake and we know it. 

I’ve seen discrimination against lgbtq people here by the deans, in small ways. None should be happening. 

Faculty meetings often include a prayer before eating which is very uncomfortable as this is a secular school and many faculty/ staff are not religious.


The workers here need a union.

review_title: Not a good place if you want growth opportunities
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Ok place to work right out of college.
cons:
When I first started working at Keiser things were great. It was my first job out of college and I felt very welcomed and supported. After about a year of working there, I started to focus on advancing in terms of knowledge and compensation. I got NONE of that. 

Raises are 3-4% and they only happen once a year. That BARELY accounts for inflation. Not only that, but professional growth is almost non existent except for few rare occasions. They do not focus at all on employee/career progression, so don’t come in expecting to grow through the ranks. 

Management doesn’t listen to the needs of their employees. They made everyone to come back full time to the office very prematurely. There were multiple outbreaks of COVID, and a lot of the times it felt like they were secretive about things and didn’t give employees a heads up in case they had been exposed to the virus. 

This was the last nail in the coffin for me. Keiser did not care about me, my health, my growth, nothing. 

While I’m grateful that they gave me the opportunity to begin my career there as a new grad, my hard work and all the effort I put in to do a good job and help students did not feel appreciated. Some managers can also be EXTREMELY toxic and unprofessional. 

If you’re thinking of working at admissions, look at it as a way to make some money while you look for something better. No one in that department is your friend. They will smile and be friendly, but will turn on you as soon as doing so is convenient.

If you’re looking to work in FA, just know that they are super understaffed, and the starting salary for the position hasn’t gone up in years. You might also end up working under some very unreasonable managers who want to overwork you as much as possible for little pay. 

Overall, I think Keiser might be ok as a first job. Don’t come in expecting to have a career. It’s very difficult to grow and you won’t get anything more than 3-4% raises even if you are a star employee. It’s a job you could stay in for about a year while you get some professional experience, but please please please don’t waste more than a couple of years hoping to grow or get very far.

review_title: Awesome pay for veteran counselors but be prepared to work for it
job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in Daytona Beach, FL
pros:
Pay can be very good (especially if you negotiate for it). I've personally had huge pay increases at review time, so basically doubled my starting salary over a 5 year period.
Company is good about transferring to different campuses, even if you quit for another job, they are good about accepting you back if you left on good terms and gave notice.
Good about working with counselors who are struggling and don't just can you quickly like other private schools do. 
They were rewarding top 10% with a cruise every year, but heard they don't do that anymore.
They do a nice retreat every year, lots of meetings, but also nice hotel and wine and dine you;)
cons:
If you don't have a good DOA you probably aren't happy; favoritism is common!
Work hours are ok but inconvenient (40 hours usually) but 9-6pm twice a week, 11-8pm twice a week, 9-5pm on Fridays and usually about 1 Saturday a month from 9-1pm.  BUT, they will make you work Sat anytime the DOA deems necessary (i.e, missing start or before a start day). Open Houses and other events in the evenings every few months.
Home for the holidays....not! Not very good about giving you enough time for holidays.
Vacation "black out" dates make it hard, especially in the summer!

review_title: I am thankful to work for such a great University.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL

It makes a huge difference to me to really be passionate about what I do and who I can help.
cons: Before I came to Keiser I had experience working at four other schools of higher education. As many of you know life is not always perfect at every work place. review_title: Manager and campus president were the reason why I stayed for almost 4 years
job_title: CRC in Tampa, FL
pros:
If you are in this position (& depending on your manager/campus president) then you will be happier than most who work at this university because you will be "out in the field" conducting presentations at local high schools. You have flexible hours compared to the admissions counselors, however, you need to be ok with working really early in the morning to get to your high school by 7 or 7:30. 

After 3 years of employment your health insurance is fully covered.
cons:
There is some negative perception of Keiser (rightfully so b/c of how some things were done in years past) and so that can make it harder to work with your local high schools. They may not want you to speak with their students. 

You only get 5 PTO days the first year. It doesn't matter if you are sick, have something personal to take care of, or want to take vacation...they are all in the  category--PTO. When you stay beyond a year it goes up, however, if you don't use those days you loose them.

review_title: Glad I researched it before the interview... Very happy!
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Lakeland, FL
pros:
- Work closely with a team: lots of playfulness and helpful feedback
- Little to no micromanaging: everyone has their own style of interacting with prospective students
- Consistent schedule
- Strong campus president, directors and assistant directors of admissions
- Focus on the best interest of the student, even if it means Keiser's not the right fit
- Staff and faculty will drop almost anything to help resolve a student issue
- Excellent benefits, on site gym, and you get paid even if college is closed
- Ongoing training
- One of the most successful Keiser campuses, with lots of tenured staff
- Each campus only offers college degrees in demand for the local geographic area, with high placement rates
cons:
- Cubicles
- Can feel like a call center: the goal is to make 100 calls a day
- 2 nights a week until 8pm + every other Saturday
- Only 5 days PTO first year
- A bit more challenging if you come from a traditional sales mentality, even if there are some similarities in techniques and training
- Sometimes lack of communication with other departments
- Takes a lot of time and effort up front with slow results at the beginning to build a pipeline of interested prospects
- The hardest part about the job is psychological: if you're not in the right mindset or don't believe in what you're doing, you're not going to see the results you want

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Orlando, FL
pros: Considering compensation of similar jobs in the industry, Keiser University pays well.  Thats about where the pros end.
cons: Administration from the campus president down through departmental management leaves a lot to be desired.  The many leadership  books that find their homes on the shelves in the offices occupied by management clearly serve solely as office decor.  There is no clear evidence that director of admissions or the campus president have attempted to implement any true leadership choosing to stick with the "manage by fear and intimidation" and "career aspirations outside of Keiser is a personal insult to us" way of guiding.  This is unfortunate because there is so much potential for this to be a great place to work.

review_title: Focused on the stuff that doesn’t matter
job_title: Instructor in Orlando, FL
pros: Decent salary. Loved being with students.
cons: Micromanagement of highly educated individuals. Minimal academic freedom.  Needed to treat students like children and take attendance daily and if It wasn’t posted to the broken interface daily, a nastigram was sent. A physical paper gradebook on top of a blackboard gradebook (I mean really folks?). A horrible LMS interface -Blackboard can do more. Faculty (exempt employees) needed to clock in and out and often are sent a nastigram via email when hours weren’t exactly at 40 hours but no accommodations given when 50 hour weeks occurred (we are faculty. Grading for a few hours a week shouldn’t be frowned upon). Office equipment and facilities that were down often. Limited functional computing access for students. Constantly changing rules and targets. Full time position have been cut without notice. All creates a culture of fear. Horrible time off - teaching on that schedule is exhausting and you’re given four weeks off you don’t get to pick.

review_title: Driven by enrollment growth not student success. Employees expendable.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Benefits are okay. Decent Location. Well-meaning supervisors.
cons:
Highly centralized upper management that is unaware of individual branch needs. 

All decisions seemingly stem from an interest in increasing enrollments and not on student success. 

A lot of positions that are typically salaried at similar institutions are hourly. Must clock in/out. Required to take 1 hour for lunch making for a 9 hour work day. 

"Customer service" is unironically used when student services is not simply a transactional relationship. 

Employees do not actually work for the institution but work with for a staffing company with no HR support on campus. 

No Title IX coordinator on campus. No Title IX training. 

There is a lot of favoritism for existing long term employees that push out new ideas and talent. 

Time off benefit is lacking and well below typical offerings in higher education. 

Employees are very friendly, but many seem very unhappy which makes for a really negative work environment.

review_title: Worst job I've ever had in my entire life.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros: The people you work with equally hate the job so you have something to bond over
cons:
You are literally a part of a scam. You are nothing more than a telemarketer. You call "prospect" students all day long. If they don't answer you call at different times during the day. You are trained to not answer their questions directly and your only goal is to get them for an "interview" at the school and convince them to enroll. You are given a quota of students you must enroll every month. If you don't make your quota, they make you work weekends. Teachers don't care about the students, the admissions counselors, directors, financial aid office - nobody cares about the students. They only care about MONEY. Dr. Keiser changed the school from for profit to not for profit but he bought the land the school is on and the school pays him "rent" for the land. He still makes a killing. I found an article online that said he makes more than his counterpart at Harvard! 
This was the absolute worst job of my entire life. I would rather go back and work fast food than ever work here again.

review_title: Avoid positions in the Nursing Program like the Plague
job_title: Nursing Faculty in Miami, FL
pros: There are no pros. Even though they give 3 weeks off paid during in December for the holidays, nursing faculty have to work to prepare for the following semester because there is inadequate prep time provided.
cons:
Long work hours-there is no work-life balance
No respect for full-time nursing educators
No administrative support, concerns are not addressed
Poor pay
Unrealistic workload, no prep time, expected to teach courses out of the specialty area
No support staff
Unqualified program director (PD)
Program director bullies students and nursing faculty, often threatens the nursing faculty
Problems and concerns from nursing faculty were ignored, despite completing a peer review from faculty regarding the PD and issues in the program
Program directer refuses to pitch in, expects staff to perform non-educational duties, and the work of 3-4 people
There is no privacy, instructors work in cubicles so conversations are overheard by other program faculty then reported to the program director
The clinical lab is a disaster, no technology integration
The program does not follow ACEN standards
There is a revolving door with regards to faculty and the administrative team believes that it is because the faculty are at fault for the issues, not the PD or administration. 
Corporate administration does not address issues
No exit interviews are provided

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Honestly, can't, think of any.  Low pay, terrible, uneducated managment, insurance more expensive than getting it yourself.  Forced to come in 15 min before shift, but can't clock in.
cons: Management will hold education against you.  Will change your hours and team at will.  Micromanagement galore. U have to ask to use the restroom.  Treated badly for asking questions or making sugestions.  Whole sales pitch is based on lies.  They base their mngmnt on threats and beration.  Directorr of admissions is an insecure, abusive, and downright mean woman with a complex about her power.  Can only be beome an assstant director if your her friend, prduction is irrelevant.  Current assistance are also mean, abusive, and threatening.  No praise for god work, only reprimands for what they call poor.  Must misrepresent programs and career paths to students.  Most calls are for programs they don't even offer.  Not allowed to tell students that a program isn't offered. Instead, were instructed to attack that; rogram and praise one we do have, while never admitting that we don't have the other program.  If one does not do this, u will.get written upfl for notpl promoting the university.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Regionally accredited - IF the student graduates they at least have a piece of paper worth something.
cons: Admissions is run like a high pressure call center. You must call at least 80-100 people a day. It doesn't matter if the people in the past have said they're not interested because they might change their mind.  What you learn at training is not what is practiced.  The official phrase is "policy vs practice." The deans don't like to deal with students.  Students are constantly dropping out and admissions make bets on how long they will last when they enroll them. Their phrase is students first, but it's really about the numbers and how many you can enroll. There is a lot of competition between the different campuses. It is a big deal when another campus "steals students" and there is no teamwork.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The front line employees are an asset to the organization.   Academics and faculty are excellent, programs meet the stringent requirements for rigorous and challenging.
cons: Leadership is inextricably tied to the "for profit, career-college" mentality.  Failure of leadership is responsible for most ongoing issues.  FP mentality considers prospectives as a "piece of business".  Poor Management skills and HR leadership = Poor employee training and development.  Little or no opportunity for front line employees to advance.  The e-campus is truly a revolving door "call center" for both employees and students that reflects a "burn and churn" philosophy.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Daytona Beach, FL
pros: The school offers some good allied health programs. They have some dedicated teachers and staff members. They provide good student services, job placement and a variety of student resources. Many of the employees work very hard to make a difference in the lives of students. Good military presence. Regionally accredited. Offer financial aid.
cons: They need to do more for their community. Should offer a variety of in-house scholarships to assist students with tuition, since tuition is much too expensive. The school equipment is not high end. The admission's team has constant turnover due to the culture; the senior counselors have between 18 months and three years experience, which is not a good sign. Disparate treatment is an issue with some people. Very little raises, if any. Unrealistic goals for the student demographic and cost of tuition. Marginal benefits. Follow through is marginal. Very little coaching and developing for some people, and plenty for others. Inconsistent.

job_title: in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: If hired, one can add experience to their curriculum vitae or resume. Tuition reimbursement is available to full-time staff and faculty.
cons: It's unfortunate that this university doesn't offer job security or professional development. It's culture is very corporate and unwelcoming. There are no remnants of higher education knowledge at all. The sharing of ideas or best practices are non-existent. The work load, be it from an instructional or administrative position, is unrealistic and burdensome. Furthermore, the salary offered for such demanding work is an insult to any professional be it entry-level or seasoned. There is a reason KU is always hiring.

job_title: Administrator in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: A steady paycheck. met one or two nice people in my time there.
cons: The building smells like mold-you would reek of that smell and all of your belongings smelled horrible from being in that building. There was inapt and unsafe parking for the number of employees in that building. There was nepotism beyond belief when it came to the people who knew the owner and family. In one particular department (SFO) if you did not speak Spanish you were not welcomed to work there anyone who they hired that was darker skinned was a token person who eventually they found a way to eliminate. If you have a problem with management or working conditions don't bother to go to HR. They will do absolutely nothing to assist you and in some cases make you feel like you are the one who is the problem.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Clearwater, FL
pros: I work as an admissions counselor and thoroughly enjoy it. I have loved every minute working here. Management takes the time to make sure you are trained, and is willing to help you be successful. Love the feedback I am giving to help myself grow as an employee and as a person! It is rewarding because you truly do what is best for the student, regardless if they end up enrolling or not. The campus president, is the best and the DOA, is even better. The whole admissions team is awesome. I would have to say that I am proud that I work at Keiser University and love working there, but I am especially proud of the fact that I work at the Clearwater location!
cons: there are no cons because working here is awesome! unless you are scared of hard work-then don't work here because you obviously have to work hard!

review_title: I work a good rewarding job on a great team but I am overworked.
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Orlando, FL
pros: They pay is good compared to other financial aid positions at other FL schools. Most student go to class on campus so you meet with them face to face. The atmosphere is close knit - the relationships among departments are very good.
cons: The team I am on is grossly overworked. I joined 8 months ago and have regularly had to work overtime. The expectations the company wants you to reach are higher than the process allows, at least with the amount of people we have. The Financial Aid policies at Keiser seem to work against the company because it slows things down unnecessarily. If you don't meet the goals - mandatory overtime.

job_title: Academic Advisor in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Pay was decent and overtime pay is good. Working with some of the staff is the only reason I hung in there as long as I did.
cons:
They are stuck with a for profit approach even though they are non for profit. Employees and students suffer because they are unwilling to make the proper changes. A lot of the systems are out of date. Advisors still have to manually add and drop every student from all of their classes. The Advising area is a ferpa violation waiting to happen. 

I wouldn’t suggest any of my friends to work here and I wouldn’t let any child of mine attend their classes until significant changes are made.

review_title: Schools, like sausages, cease to inspire respect in proportion to how much we know of their processes.
job_title: Financial Aid Administrator in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Fort Myers Campus. The culture created by those at the campus level. 401k match. Location. On site management (campus president, directors, professors, etc.) Earnest student friendly environment. Competent & comprehensive services.
cons: The disconnect between HQ or senior management (i.e. office of chancellor and central processing) & satellite campuses. Clumsy micromanagement from corporate. Low promotion ceiling. Irrelevant, inefficient, and redundant policy pushing. Regarding most of the Pros above, all campuses are not created equally and the cultures therein vary widely.

review_title: Don't do more, it will not get you anywhere
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tampa, FL
pros: Good students. Nice building. Fun activities on campus for employees and students. Good benefits.
cons:
Promotion is about who you know, not what you achieve.  If you are friends with the deans then you have it made. Fake an illness and you will be promoted. If you work hard and don't buddy up with the deans, then you will not be promoted. Warning. The campus president doesn't keep up with what is happening on the faculty side and the faculty suffer. Faculty are asked to be everything from administrators, to recruiters, to deans. There's very little time to be professors. Upper management and deans delegate as much as possible, but to people who are already overworked and underpaid. 
Professors are asked to stalk students, even following graduation. It's just an unfriendly place to work.
Other campuses are not this draconian and unfriendly.

job_title: Faculty in Tallahassee, FL
pros: Faculty are upbeat, positive and professional.  They do care about the students. Salaries are very good.
cons: President with an open door philosophy who's door is always closed.  Nothing gets done on the campus without the approval of the campus president.  Upper and middle  management are hostile, bullying,belittling and totally ineffective. The president doesn't want to remove ineffectual managers as it would be embarrassing. I should have guessed that there were going to be problems when they couldn't decide what job I was applying for!

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Good entry level job if you have no life. Good "admissions" experience. Decent pay.
cons: Management is terrible and when admissions is doing badly they just blame the counselors and write you up to scare you. They do not respect your personal time, expect you to work over time and never take a day off. You have to work two saturdays a month and stay late on orientation. Students are looked at as numbers and not really as "making a difference." All business oriented. The higher ups do not value admissions counselors. You have to make 100 calls a day or you will be scolded. You follow an interview script that is 100 years old when interviewing students. If you are a minute late you are scolded (but they expect you to stay late).

review_title: Admissions: Get paid to ruin lives
job_title: Admissions in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros: I learned that I hate sales
cons:
They lie to you and say its not sales. It is. All they care about is money money money. They try to brainwash employees, saying you are changing lives by convincing people to go in debt for a $50,000 associates degree (wtf?). Well you are, for the worse that is. 

This "university" should be shut down. Basically if you can speak English and do simple math they will admit you as a student, setting you up for failure. I feel like I work for Satan.

Also, there is no advancement opportunity. The only reason some people stay is because they are making bloated salaries left over from when Kaiser was a for profit school and was showering admissions reps with money for enrolling students.

job_title: Admissions in Orlando, FL
pros: Helping people find their path is rewarding.
cons:
Management would rather use scare tactics and emotional abuse than lead with anything silly like encouragement or motivation. Work like a slave, never question anyone's decision, and be micromanaged like you're an idiot (took a 16 min break instead of a 15 min break? You're getting a write up). Please don't mistake this for bitterness. This is truth. I work her because I have people to support and just haven't found a better job yet.

There's this lovely culture of back-stabbing in this high-pressure, call center-like job. 

Insurance for employee + child will run you around $1000/ month (for the mid-range plan). After 3 years of working in hell, your insurance for yourself is free. They also claim you can take classes for free as an employee, but no one ever gets approved unless you know someone higher up.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros: Pay is decent. Staff and faculty are welcoming and helpful. Location is good. Benefits are good for individus. Overtime is offered on a regular.
cons: No true vacation days. You have to work most holidays, cannot use vacation days during winter holidays. PTO Blackout is July thru October, can only request PPLOduring week 2 or 3 of the month. Its all about the numbers and enrollments. Very sales driven. Hours are long, weeks are long. They say they want everyone to balance work and family however you can barely request time off without calling HR directly.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Salary is very high to start. That's about it.
cons: Too many to name. I worked in F/A and Admissions and F/A do not get along. My FAD was a pushover and never supported us when it came to Admissions. This company is run like a mom and pop shop. They only mainly their friends and family. These people didn't have to try to get the job so they know they can screw up all the  time and nothing will ever happen to them. Everyone in F/A in the online division is from Trinidad. The FAD is from Trinidad. Coincidence? Of course not. All these people did very little work and screwed up their files all the time because they knew the FAD would do their work for them. If you weren't one of his Trini pets, he left you out to dry.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Tampa, FL
pros: *Overtime was available year round.
cons:
** I am only writing this so someone in management can read it and hopefully improve the culture at Keiser. 
-Admissions counselors are only allowed to take PTO certain weekends of the month. Sometimes you are scheduled to work the one or two weekends where you could have requested time off. No work life balance. Only five days of PTO per year. 
-Management is terrible. They don't make as many phone calls at the admissions counselors. One of the senior admissions counselors was extremely sexist (I will spare you the examples). He would come in early before everyone else and sort through the leads so he could get the easy appointments or walk in leads. The senior admissions counselor thought he was the mobster of Keiser. Other counselors would say "Oh you don't want to get on his bad side". He also had a filthy mouth and complained about the smell of the admissions counselor lunches. He just wasn't used to healthy smelling food. He would constantly bully admissions counselors and had a problem when admissions counselors would speak with a student that was assigned to him, even  thought he made zero effort in contacting the student. 
-The counselors have filthy mouths. One counselor said she would announce to the whole office when someone defecated on the first floor bathroom.
-The office has a huge race problem. They don't like "vanilla". 
-One counselor told me I am "lucky" to have such a "great job" at my age. They don't like young people. 
-I worked seven holidays in a row, this was a "gift" from the director because during the holidays no one is working and I would be able to get lots of "inquiries" 
-The school has such terrible reviews online that students would bring up the reviews during their interview, making it hard to convince them it was a good school. 
- Admissions counselors are expected to work two Saturdays a month, stay until 8:00 for orientation, and arrive at 7:30 AM for start days. Despite these hours and mandatory overtime, management has a problem when admissions counselors adjust their schedule by 15 minutes. 
-The office is dated, and often has flies back there. It is always hot in the office.
 -The computer equipment and headsets is dated. The computers are always slow. 
-The instructors view admissions counselors as sleazy sales people. Instructors are always asking what students are signing up for their class/program. 
-Not a team environment, everyone gossips about everyone else. Mean jokes about managers. 
-The Senior admissions counselor was in charge of PTO, if he felt you weren't "performing", he would advise not to take PTO because it would "hurt" you. 
-Everyone wants to get promoted. Too many captains and not enough sailors. 
-President is clueless about what goes on in the admissions office. 
-Counselors would fight over inquiries and the directors did not want to get involved, like hello that their job. 
-Last, but probably most important, the director was never in the office. She would leave the building for hours at a time and constantly take days off. The team questioned if she was resigning because she was absent so much. She spent more time in the offices of other departments than she would with her own team. It was ironic she would say something about me being 5-6 minutes  late, when she wouldn't come in until 11:30 AM sometimes! She was never in her office when her team needed her. I was "talked to" about tweaking my schedule, yet management is not on any time of schedule. It is a joke. 
-The whole school seems like a joke, I would never recommend this place to a friend. 
-I am glad I left when I did, I wish I left sooner. The sad part, is I didn't mind the job, it was the people and the management that chased me away. I enjoyed meeting with students. I didn't enjoy the nasty gossip, cliques, and nasty attitudes of management. 
                                                                     .

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Daytona Beach, FL
pros: Good pay, that's it, but at least five words are required in this category to post.
cons:
Incredibly toxic work environment, high turnover of employees, mental and verbal abuse by superiors, no HR on site to assist, any HR complaints were sent to immediate supervisor prior to being sent to HR so any complaints about supervisory styles were never sent on, the director of admissions was caught adjusting time clocks so employees would not accumulate overtime and is still in his position, the school buys student information and calls each one a minimum of 5 times a week unless they explicitly say "remove me from your list", do not make students aware of financial burden Keiser will put them in, only worried about numbers.

I worked here for a month and a half before I could no longer take the toxic environment and quite within minutes of receiving a job offer elsewhere.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tampa, FL
pros: Rewarding teamwork with colleagues and helping the community. Campus culture allows collaboration but also has high accountability due to family-like environment (think siblings!). Dedication is required and “paycheck collectors” don’t fit in. The work is busy, so time doesn’t drag. Some really fun and funny people make even tough tasks and difficult weeks enjoyable.
cons: For most positions, this is not an 8-5 job. There are day night and online students, and staff and faculty need to be here to support all of them. Students first philosophy inherently meanS employees second. That’s understood from the beginning, but selfish employees who are not here for student success don’t see that as a pro.

review_title: Do not work here.  Terrible people work here
job_title: Fina in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: none if you are a smart person with integrity
cons: weak manager, other people in power are bullies and extremely unprofessional. this place runs like a small mom and pop shop.  they exist almost totally on nepitism.  everyone is someone's sister, mother, brother, best friend, cousin, etc. so there are alot of people in positions that did not earn them therefore they have no idea what they are doing.  This was the worst job I ever had.

job_title: Faculty in Sarasota, FL
pros: (1) flexible scheduling for faculty--you must work a set number of hours but aside from class time how you put those in is pretty much up to you (2) 4 weeks paid vacation plus five pto days for full time faculty (scheduling must be during semester breaks and with permission of admin. During other times) (3) employer matches 4 percent on 401(k) contributions (4) variety of insurance plans to choose from (5) supportive work environment (it must vary from campus to campus because I work in Sarasota and I do not recognize the work environment described in some of the other reviews. ) (6) because of the small campus size you become very familiar with individual students and what learning styles are best for them.  (7)most of our students have overcome a lot of obstacles to be here and when they successfully complete a class or a program and obtain employment in their field you feel really good about being a part of making that happen!
cons: (1) the media has a hard-on for Keiser.  Much of it is unjustified, at least on the campus where I work, and it unfairly hurts the public perception of what we do. The bottom line is we are accredited and we wouldn't be if we did any of the things we are accused of in the press.2) while we strive to make a college degree accessible to non-traditional students, the cost of coming here can make that impossible.  (3) there are malcontents in every workplace.  If your goal is to make a lot of money, achieve recognition, or be treated like a special snowflake, this is not the workplace for you.  You are there to serve the students, not yourself.  (4) opportunities to move up the ladder are limited because most faculty and admin stay here long term and there are few full time openings.  (5) lots of paperwork required in order to keep accreditation--much of it redundant.  Takes the focus away from interacting with our students which is what we should be doing instead.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in New Port Richey, FL
pros: Good pay for the area.  Work one on one with students.  Work with great counselors, faculty, and staff.  School has potential.
cons: Benefits.  Work, life, balance.  Supervisor turns team against one another for enrollments,  not a team environment.  Students First Motto is out the window with some, they only care about numbers and not about the students.  Are not growing the campus the right way.  Glorified sales job, counselors get fussed at when they try to counsel and mentor current students.  Told that is an academics issues, not an admissions.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Orlando, FL
pros: Keiser can be a fun place to work. Cubicles allow you to see and hear and speak to anyone at any given time.
cons: Mandatory overtime, blackout periods unrealistic to any life balance, two to three weekends a month, favoritism from the top down, high tuition for a general degree, low if any pay raises unless you are a favorite at the time or review, no growth.

review_title: Do not accept Admission Counslor Position!!!
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The people are the best, your teammates become family and a maybe one or two ADOA's are really good people. Money good for new comers only, off days get better longer you stay. Decent work life balance after your second year.
cons: Omg, where do I start, managers are friends and never took a management class. Promotion are hard unless you kiss their bottom. Hours sucks, pay raises for the amount of money you bring per semester sucks. It's a call center but they try to conver it up, don't fall for the changing lives crap. No set career path, no growth.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros: It's a learning experience and you could have a positive impact on someone that wants to start school,  if Keiser doesn't get in your way.
cons: You are working for a deceitful system that expects you to make sales out of people's desire to go back to school by sometimes humiliating them and calling them out on their lack of commitment or financial misgivings. You're not a counselor,  but a glorified sales rep that is expected to make over a hundred calls a day from your cubicle.  Some of the campuses have corrupt deans and admissions directors that are trying to maintain numbers and increase sales.  Something that is required by this organization for people to keep their jobs.

job_title: Admissions in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Most coworkers are friendly.  Decent benefits that are paid in full after 3 years of employment which is rare today!  Armed security upon entry.  Overtime is NOT an issue here, work until you drop if you so desire.
cons: Management has obvious favorites.  Long hours.  Building is old and very cold.  No employee kitchen/break room.  Bathrooms can get pretty disgusting.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros: Regionally accredited and amazing faculty that teach and prepare the students for a career. Hard working staff that want to grow and develop within the company.
cons: The company does not accurately represent themselves as it relates to the admissions expectations and requirements for success. They harass and use fear and intimidation to get the desired results. There is no work life balance. The hours are over and above other school groups. There is favoritism and no room for advancement for the majority that work there. The goals are unrealistic for the current market and programs offered. There is limited training for new staff and no training manuals to self teach.

review_title: A rewarding experience meeting with new people on a daily business.
job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The company is family oriented with excellent benefits. The work environment is fast paced and geared towards helping people obtain a career based education.
cons: Often the company requires working overtime, evenings and on weekends. The work is often at a pace that many are not able to keep up with, and stress runs high as goals are set at a level that is hard to maintain.

review_title: Great place to Work. Great place to gain experience and friendly people.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Great friendly co-workers and calm environment. It has activities that also involve the staff and I think that was a good choice. The programs are great if you are thinking about returning to school. I believe is has room to grow into something great with the right people.
cons: Nothing important, only a few good choices for lunch. The leadership is great but can use alittle work. Just understand what you are getting into.

review_title: Your boss will throw you under the bus in a heart beat.
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Ummmmmmmm I am still working there and trust me I cannot think of any pros.
cons: Plenty. Make sure you always meet goals or you will get written up. They do not honor 2 weeks notices. Compensation suck.  Vacation days also it very bad, you do not have sick days, you only get 1 week after 90 days, and then 2 weeks after 1 year (that is if you survive that long).

job_title: in Sarasota, FL
pros: The students are sweet.  After several years paid medical.  Vacation time after 1 year.
cons: Nepotism and greed, not student focused.  Managers and president more interested in keeping there jobs than developing school, staff, and students.  Look up their lawsuits.

job_title: Instructor in Tampa, FL
pros: Flexible schedule outside of class times. Very intelligent and friendly colleagues. Working with many of the students can be very rewarding. The school is expanding and adding many extra-curricular activities for the students.
cons: Interactions with staff (non-faculty) can be off-putting as they have very different goals than faculty and do not appreciate what goes on in the classroom. Some students are very difficult to work with.

review_title: Are all Adjunct college teachers paid and treated the same?
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros:
I love teaching at the college level. I have been in my field for over 25 years and am still passionate about it.  Since Keiser is a career oriented college,  and the course I teach is in general education , I don't have to deal with the publish or perish aspects of academia.
I worked in public schools prior to my time at Keiser, . I wasn't teaching, but still working with students.
What I do is gratifying, and I am glad that I have a job. However, it still matters to me what I am compensated and we are not allowed to talk to our colleagues on this topic.
cons:
There is no opportunity to be rewarded finacially for a job well done. There have been three administraion changes in something like four  years. Things seem to improve, but it does give one a feeling of instability.  Even the student body comments about it.
Since it is a private univserity, student opinions matter.  Of course, only the negative aspects.  If they complain about you, you will be sure to hear about it, and possibly be let go.  On the other hand, no matter how much work you do, nor how much the students surveys say they love you, you get nothing. On the envelope of my paycheck, the former president  ( at least that's what it was signed) would sometimes write things like, "thanks for the great job you do"  Two weeks ago I came in on  Friday and there was the receptionist, writing a similar comment on EVERYONE'S envelope.  Nothing like mass production to make you feel important.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tampa, FL
pros:
- free health insurance after 3 years
- EASY job no matter what department you work in. Admissions seems to be the only one that requires some micromanaging but other departments are very relaxed
- Quiet and beautiful campus
- you can take many breaks. People take smoke breaks all the time or just breaks to go talk to your coworkers
- depending on the department, you can go the whole day minding your business and getting your work done
cons:
If you enjoy career advancement and want to grow in a professional way, then this place is NOT for you. There is absolutely no career advancement. Transferring to another department is the most "common" move, but any type of movement here is rare. This is a major disadvantage if you are young and looking to grow. 

Since it's a small private location, gossiping is at an all time high here. Its ridiculous! Gossiping is a full time job for many employees. I know gossip is everywhere, but this place thrives in the field of gossip (especially managers). It leaves a bad feeling in your stomach - whether you're involved or not.

There is no HR. NONE! If you or someone else has an issue, good luck being respected as an employee. I have seen a number of employees try to address an issue and then it's reported to corporate office. Corporate lets Tampa know - then the employee gets "pushed" out. Keiser doesn't like to fire people, they like to persuade these individuals to leave on their own, or they find a dumb reason to let someone go even though many of their employees are hardly doing their jobs as it is. 

This place seems to be good at first, but people get in a rut here. People get stuck and they are comfortable with just staying where they are. They become comfortable with the gossip and become comfortable with the immoral acts that occur here. Don't get me wrong - there are plenty of good and honest employees... but knowing what I know now and see how they push to enroll students just to get their numbers... I would have stayed away. I didn't feed proud to have worked at Keiser and not many people do. It sucks the life out of many people.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Amazing people that work there. Very fair with generous vacation schedule. Pay is good. Great management at the online campus. If you are exceeding expectations and going the extra mile you will be looked at for promotion. I would definitely recommend this place to work.
cons: The only people expressing dissatisfaction with the position are either not putting the work in to be successful or they're not a good fit to work there. No cons here.

review_title: Hard to believe anyone in management actually took a management course
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Let me think...none that come to mind.  It is sad that admissions is still run like a sales department.  Anyone seen Boiler room?
cons: Did anyone in management in any part of the company actually take a management class.   I mean just because you are friends with someone doesn't mean the former school bus driver is qualified to be the head of the online division.

job_title: Student Federal Work Study in Jacksonville, FL
pros: flexible work hours, super friendly staff, choosing which departments to help, relatively easy, great for those who have never gotten a job but need experience and also need flexible work hours.
cons: The limited amount of time per week for hours ( mine was 10 max ), sometimes all the paperwork and filing can give you paper cuts, its a little boring, no pay raise, you must have something to do or some department to help or else you have to leave early and no hours.

review_title: if you thought skin color doesnt matter...IT DOES HERE
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: the pay, great for job for post grad
cons: Nepotism, a very apparent racist system in terms of promoting. The employees are 95% latino and black yet no matter how long or how much one excels, the new white employee with less experience, no leadership skills, constanly late will always advance over you

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Fort Lauderdale, FL

The process for admission and financial aid is extremely rushed and there are a lot of road blocks when student end up enrolling for classes but haven't completed the financial aid process. The work load is heavy and there isn't much time to get things done.

I was hired for a position but was then put in an administrative role (not the hired position) for 8 months without proper training.

job_title: Librarian in West Palm Beach, FL

Secretive reasons for firing individuals which are legal according to the letter of employment all employees are forced to sign if you want to work for Keiser University - LEGALLY CAN TERMINATE EMPLOYEE WITH OR WITHOUT CAUSE WITH OR WITHOUT NOTICE...in other words, if upper management doesn't like the color of your hair, they meet secretly, invent an excuse, and fire you on the spot even if you have never been warned, written up, or are under a probationary period.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Pembroke Pines, FL

Extreme hypocrisy; being an admissions counselor for a for-profit (regardless of what is said, it IS for profit) university is a SALES JOB plain and simple. Treat it like a sales job and people will know what to expect. They hire educated people and treat them like stupid children.

job_title: Faculty in Tampa, FL
pros: experience and if you have a good president and program director and co-faculty, you are lucky
cons: Too expensive for students and too controlling for faculty. Salary not near enough. Don't get me started on that mandatory yearly farce called Convocation

review_title: Over rated, terrible to their students, cheap

Computer systems are a disaster, and they have a large IT program on campus.  Adjunct professors are treated like garbage, even though they teach most of the classes on campus.  Students are treated badly by financial aid, admissions, and most every department on campus.

job_title: Instructor in Tallahassee, FL

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Jacksonville, FL

The campus president is completely unprofessional and very inappropriate.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Hard working colleagues, decent company benefits - paid medical after 3 years.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL

review_title: To care daily tasks as needed

Students know that if they complain to Deans, grades will be raised.  a complete sham of a school. Deans and middle management is a politburo mentality following a completely misguided mission.

review_title: Hostile Work Environment. High turnover rate
job_title: Instructor in Orlando, FL

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Fort Lauderdale, FL

review_title: They're gonna lie to you. This is sales.

review_title: Undecided About My Experience at KU
job_title: College Professor in Tampa, FL
pros: It would appear on initial inspection that there is a friendly atmosphere on the campus...but....
cons: The campus is plauged by poor management, but it appears that management is hamstrung by the main office in Ft. Lauderdale which does not allow much autonomy.

job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in Clearwater, FL
pros:
Great co-works
Caring management
Ability to grow as a professional
This is a tough job. A lot is expected of you. You will be held accountable to the expectations given to you. Have honest and to the point answers.

pros:
Very Military style of Management. They remind you every day you are lucky to have a job. After a while you are brainwashed and scared to leave.   Raises are 1% or 2% if you get one at all. 
They let you sleep at your desk. They don’t give raises but they feed you all the pizza you can handle provided that you work every weekend and Holiday.  You need no education to succeed, they will educate you there way. You job will be only doing one thing and you will not be trained or used for anything outside of what they want you to do. You will grow old and not grow. If you are ambitious, then you will be written up for not following your one task and going off course.  The medical benefits however you cant use them because you work nights, weekends and Every Holiday. No such thing as a 3 day weekend, Christmas or Thanksgiving. They keep you till the final hour.
cons: . If you don’t come in, they fire you. Management is a "Boys Club" and the men are pigs. if you are not related, young naïve and can be exploited by brainwashing  please apply, this will be a learning experience.  Admissions are told to enroll anyone with a pulse. They even log in for students so they get credit for the enrollment to meet numbers and the students are charged! Management knows this and turns a blind eye! Financial Aid is told to forge financial aid documents using paint and Photoshop. Instructors jobs are threated if they don’t pass there students regardless if they show up or not.  It is a diploma Mill for sure. They even enrolled people with no high school diploma! All is illegal, they have paid fines. Be prepared  They will work you on Holidays, weekends, nights and you will have no life. Don't call in sick or you will be written up, even if you have the time to take. No Vacations of any kind. They have to go through 3 layers of Management and always are declined regardless of the circumstances, i.e.; wedding, honeymoon, graduations.. Forget it!!! They don't care about you!!! Only there bottom line!

DO NOT ACCEPT THIS JOB UNLESS YOU ARE DESPERATE!!!

job_title: Admissions Counselor in Titusville, FL
pros: Good pay ($18.27 an hour starting) & great coworkers
cons: Where do I begin? You're told during the interview process that you will be meeting with students, offering career counseling, and finding qualified candidates to enroll into the school. You'll quickly learn that a qualified candidate is one that simply has the $55 application fee. Management will tell you over and over that this isn't a sales job, that you're changing lives and finding qualified candidates. This is 100% a sales job. You will be required to make 80-100 calls every day from inquiries that can be over 5 years old. You'll have a certain number of enrollments you'll need to reach per month. You will be questioned why students you met with did not enroll and why they want to visit other schools. The management is completely out of touch & have no leadership skills. They often treat you as if you're a child, speaking to you in condescending tones and exploding if you ask a question that they think you should already know the answer to. There are many unwritten rules and policies that are not listed in any handbook. You receive five PTO days for your first year (this includes both sick and personal time) and you have a 3 month "blackout period" during the summer. You are required to work long hours (10 or 11 hour days are required) and often several Saturdays a month. If you happen to collect overtime, you will be required to adjust your schedule so as to not exceed 40 hours. There is no work/life balance & the turnover rate is unbelievable.

pros:

They wont threaten to fire u till u reach.about one year and a half. Then they wll ride u and start writing u up..so ur safe for that long.
cons:
A great percentages of the admissions counselor have never.received.a raise. They will find plenty of things wrong so they wont have to give you a yearly raise, Benchmarks and goals are 10 enrollments per person a month and they just increased the outbound calls to 75 per person.  

The salary is not competitive, everyone starts at 35,000 a year, regardless if u have a masters or not. IIn the past if you worked the graduate program they use to compensate you and pay 40,000 but they no longer do that. They combined the graduate school with the undergraduate school, so who ever they hire for the graduate program will make 35000 now. So the olds school grad counselors make 40000 to near 50000. They were lucky, but now anyone that come on will make 35,000. There are a few senior AC that makes 40-45000. That's about it. However. I hear they are no longer compensating any new senior ac. 

 They have tuition reimbursement. But if you take it you will owe the time. Meaning. If you go to school there for two years for free then you have to work an extra two years.  If u leave before then, u will have to pay it back. Also tuition reimbursement doesn't come in effect till one year after and that goes for their 401/3k doesn't come in effect till one yea later too. 

Oh my, there medical insurance i high!!! its like 300 a month for one person. If you have insurance with them for two years. Then after 2 full years starting on the 3rd year, the medical insurance i free. But you have to be enrolled in it for 2 full years. And that's if you make it 2 full years which is really 3 years! No one really takes it.

Management is horrible. They hire their friends. They have no strategies on how to train their team. All they would like you is get an enrollment so when they have their.start meeting with their doa they have less explaining. Then when the student cancels for some reason they will ride u and lie on you big time!. Yet they encouraged u to enroll them. 

They have a trainer that was an ADOA who is now a ADOA,.. I wont comment.
They do have a new trainer that works the floor, she is from another school. She is great. ey 

They recently hired a new ADOA from another school. That is also great, which I think will bring a lot to the table and be able to train his/her AC's well!!!!

They do have a few ADOA's that was hired because, they know upper management  who has no business being an ADOA.. A certain ADOA loves to use scare tactics on their AC's

With the proper training I think there may be hope. I also personally think that Dr. Keiser, doesn't know what goes on in Admissions. I am sure, if he did none of what goes on would be happening. 

That place has so much favoritism and the ADOA's are clueless. and really its not all of the ADOA;s and it wont be hard to find out who... Just ask a few AC's on the floor. Online division!!!
